description: Probabilistic Error Cancellation (PEC) is the only known quantum error mitigation technique that yields an unbiased estimator of the ideal expectation value. The price for this exactness is an exponential sampling overhead.

The key insight is that the ideal (noiseless) operation can be expressed as a linear combination of noisy implementable operations with real-valued (possibly negative) quasi-probability coefficients. By sampling noisy circuits according to the absolute values of these coefficients and weighting results by their signs, the ideal expectation value is recovered in expectation.
PEC was proposed simultaneously with ZNE and requires a detailed noise model, typically obtained via gate set tomography or cycle benchmarking.
how_it_works: Characterize the noise channel \(\mathcal{E}_i\) for each gate \(G_i\) in the circuit, so that the noisy implementation is \(\mathcal{N}_i = \mathcal{E}_i \circ \mathcal{G}_i\).

Decompose each ideal gate as \(\mathcal{G}_i = \sum_\alpha \eta_{i,\alpha} \, \mathcal{O}_{i,\alpha}\) where \(\mathcal{O}_{i,\alpha}\) are implementable noisy operations and \(\eta_{i,\alpha}\) are quasi-probability coefficients (can be negative).
For each circuit sample: randomly choose an operation \(\mathcal{O}_{i,\alpha}\) for each gate with probability \(|\eta_{i,\alpha}| / C_i\) where \(C_i = \sum_\alpha |\eta_{i,\alpha}|\).
Execute the sampled circuit and weight the measurement result by the product of signs \(\prod_i \text{sgn}(\eta_{i,\alpha_i})\) and the total one-norm \(\prod_i C_i\).
Average over many samples to estimate the ideal expectation value.

bias_variance.notes: PEC is unbiased in the infinite-sample limit, but the sampling overhead grows exponentially as e^{2γ} where γ is the total one-norm of the quasi-probability decomposition. This makes PEC impractical for deep circuits or high noise rates.

advantages: Unbiased estimator — converges to the exact ideal value
Theoretically well-understood with rigorous error bounds
Works for any noise channel that can be characterized
Can be combined with Pauli twirling to simplify the required noise model
disadvantages: Requires detailed noise characterization (e.g., gate set tomography)
Sampling overhead is exponential in circuit depth and noise rate
Impractical for deep circuits or high noise levels
Noise model drift between calibration and execution can introduce bias
use_cases: Short-depth circuits where sampling budget is not limiting
Theoretical benchmark for comparing other mitigation techniques
Combined with Pauli twirling for simplified noise model
Verifying results from biased methods like ZNE
